texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fedora 15 was released with some updates to allow for  consistent network device names . Once it's installed, you'll end up with network devices that are named something other than eth0, eth1, and so on.
texts.text: Fedora 15 was released with some updates to allow for  consistent network device names . Once it's installed, you'll end up with network devices that are named something other than eth0, eth1, and so on.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For example, all onboard ethernet adapters are labeled as emX (em1, em2…) and all PCI ethernet adapters are labeled as pXpX (p[slot]p[port], like p7p1 for port 1 on slot 7). Ethernet devices within Xen virtual machines aren't adjusted.
texts.text: For example, all onboard ethernet adapters are labeled as emX (em1, em2…) and all PCI ethernet adapters are labeled as pXpX (p[slot]p[port], like p7p1 for port 1 on slot 7). Ethernet devices within Xen virtual machines aren't adjusted.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This may make sense to people who swap out the chassis on servers regularly and they don't want to mess with hard-coding MAC addresses in network configuration files. Also, it should give users predictable names even if a running system's drives are inserted into a newer hardware revision of the same server.
texts.text: This may make sense to people who swap out the chassis on servers regularly and they don't want to mess with hard-coding MAC addresses in network configuration files. Also, it should give users predictable names even if a running system's drives are inserted into a newer hardware revision of the same server.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, I don't like this on my personal dedicated servers and I prefer to revert back to the old way of doing things. Getting back to eth0 is pretty simple and it only requires a few configuration files to be edited followed by a reboot.
texts.text: However, I don't like this on my personal dedicated servers and I prefer to revert back to the old way of doing things. Getting back to eth0 is pretty simple and it only requires a few configuration files to be edited followed by a reboot.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
title Fedora (2.6.40.4-5.fc15.x86_64)
	root (hd0,0)
	kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.6.40.4-5.fc15.x86_64 ro root=/dev/md0 SYSFONT=latarcyrheb-sun16 KEYTABLE=us biosdevname=0 quiet LANG=en_US.UTF-8
	initrd /boot/initramfs-2.6.40.4-5.fc15.x86_64.img
texts.text:
title Fedora (2.6.40.4-5.fc15.x86_64)
	root (hd0,0)
	kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.6.40.4-5.fc15.x86_64 ro root=/dev/md0 SYSFONT=latarcyrheb-sun16 KEYTABLE=us biosdevname=0 quiet LANG=en_US.UTF-8
	initrd /boot/initramfs-2.6.40.4-5.fc15.x86_64.img

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: in your favorite text editor (create it if it doesn't exist) and add in the following:
texts.text: in your favorite text editor (create it if it doesn't exist) and add in the following:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Be sure to put your MAC addresses in the fields below
SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", ATTR{address}=="00:11:22:33:44:10", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth0"
SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", ATTR{address}=="00:11:22:33:44:11", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth1"
texts.text:
# Be sure to put your MAC addresses in the fields below
SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", ATTR{address}=="00:11:22:33:44:10", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth0"
SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", ATTR{address}=="00:11:22:33:44:11", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth1"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to match the device names you've assigned. Just for good measure, I add in the MAC address in
texts.text: to match the device names you've assigned. Just for good measure, I add in the MAC address in

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Reboot the server and you should be back to eth0 and eth1 after a reboot.
texts.text: Reboot the server and you should be back to eth0 and eth1 after a reboot.
